title: Portrait of Cardinal Zelada

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of oil on panel.

description: Anton Raphael Mengs worked for princely clients in Dresden, Madrid, Naples, and Rome, and was an early promoter of the Neoclassical style in art and writing. Francesco Saverio Zelada, depicted here, was an enthusiast of the arts and sciences who eventually rose to the position of Secretary of State for the Vatican. This work was probably commissioned when Zelada was made a cardinal in 1773. The sitter proudly holds a biretta, the scarlet cap traditionally worn by cardinals. Meng’s masterful use of color and texture to enhance the status of his sitters is on full display here through the evocation of silk, lace, fur, and ruddy ﬂesh.
credit_line: Purchased with funds provided by Silvain and Arma Wyler Foundation

exhibition_history:
Rome, Palazzo delle Esposizioni, Il Settecento a Roma, March 19 - May 31, 1959, cat. 1451.

Chicago, Art Institute of Chicago, The Art of the Edge: European Frames 1300-1900, October 17 - December 14, 1986, cat. 25.
provenance_text: Cardinal Francesco Saverio de Zelada (died 1801), Rome, until 1801.  Probably Marchese Pierfrancesco Rinuccini (died circa 1852), Florence, by 1845 [see Rinuccini catalogue, 1845, p. 17, no. 16].  Antonio Baccelli, Rome, 1959 [lent to Rome 1959].  Marcello and Carlo Sestieri, Rome, 1959; sold to the Art Institute, 1969.
